3rd. Will fill first by fractions of second. The reason I state it so certainly is is two things. First and the main one is Bernoulli's principle the second is the Venturi effect. Fluids are basically react the same, while liquids are non compressible they can compress so ever slightly when passing through a Venturi the fluid on upstream side backs up while passing through the venturi causing a minute increase in pressure according to Bernoulli's principle as the speed of the fluid increases thru the Venturi the pressures drops in the Venturi (how a carburetor pulls fuel into the engine) then as the fluid leaves the venturi it goes to it's previous pressure that it was before the Venturi minus the friction loss which keeps the outlet side at a slightly lower pressure until the flow stops. So all things being equal their will be a minute buildup of fluid in front of the tube between C and D and combined with the friction loss while traveling thru said tube there will be a minute pressure drop in the friction meaning that C will fill a fraction of a second before D.

The entire reason that these memes ARE memes is because there is a small/subtle degree of ambiguity. That stirs up controversy - causes protracted conversations and the meme is spread to more people. In this case, the clearest ambiguity is around the term "FULL". If "full" means "kinda full to close to the top" - then 3 wins. But if it means "absolutely to the top" then depending on whether you can neglect the flow rates of the pipes, etc - then it's a tie between 3 and 4...and if you don't neglect that, then it's 3 again. Of course if the flow rate through the pipes is substantially less than the input - then 1 fills up first - or the race between 3 and 4 becomes unequal.The point is that the question is carefully framed for ambiguity - and that sparks controversy and spreads the meme. It was exactly the same with "Airplane on a treadmill" and "What color is the dress?" - they ALL depend critically on some ambiguity in the wording. What color were the lights in the room where the dress was photographed? What camera was used - and with what settings? Are we talking "diffuse" color or "specular" color - and is the dress a lambertian reflector? Every single time one of these annoying memes shows up - it's 100% down to the unspoken conditions. The most viral memes are those where the average person DOESN'T consider things like the flow rate into tank #1 versus the diameter of the pipes between the tanks. This is left to our imaginations - and some people imagine fast water flow and others slow. Some people interpret "full" in different ways. Ultimately, the answer to the question posed is 100% all about human nature and 0% due to physics.

Technically 3 would spill first due to the time it takes the water to level out into 4, fluid movement is still limited by the laws of physics. The faster liquid is going into 3 the more it will overflow compared to 4. Even if the drip is slower than the flow rate of the connection between 3 and 4, 3 will still overflow first, it's just unlikely to be humanly noticeable (and that's not accounting for surface tension at the rim... taking surface tension into account means that 3 or 4 would randomly spill over first if the feed is slow enough, but that would also assume a relatively perfect container construction and setup and is also meaning you're defining an overflow as spill-over instead of simply rising above the rim. If you define it as any water above the rim then 3 will ALWAYS overflow first.).

5:43 A fills until it reaches the drain to B, then stops going up. B fills until reaching the drain to J (the drain from C to D is capped, so no flow there). J will fill and also start filling the drain to I, until the level reaches the draw to L. It will then drain through L, through the bottom drain in L to fill the horizontal tube. Then F will start to fill (the tube is capped on the H side). F will fill until the level reaches the level of L's bottom, then both will fill together until F finally fills all the way and overflows. Then L will stop filling. Some fluid will enter the space around G, the rest will fall off the right edge. If we keep going, eventually the space around G will fill, and start spilling into G. The "full "level of G is still below the overflow level of F, so that's it. After floods over, and G also fills up, the fluid will all flow out the right edge.
Edit for completeness: I, K, D, E, and H will get no fluid at all in them. F fills first, then G, then all new liquid overflows off the right side of F.

I look at this from a different perspective, real world!
The 1 or A tank fills first on both the main riddle, and the more complex one shown at the end.
I have actually worked with such things ranging from water treatment and industrial processes to doing the grade setting while building cascading wastewater ponds.

So in the real world, "Full" is defined as the maximum level the tank is designed reach, which is often defined by the presence of an overflow port.

In the replicated blueprint, Tank 1 is the surge tank, and is only designed to fill up to the level of the pipe to Tank 2. It is designed this way to keep sand and such out of the system, and it is so large in case there is a abnormal surge of liquid, such as when the bench collapses, it can overfill some and then meter it into the system. But it is defined as being full if it is at the level of the outflow pipe.

Now Tank 2 is just for aeration, gives a good splash and churn.

Tank 3 is for separating clear water from floating debris, so it has the outflow port near the bottom of the water column so that the floating debris doesn't get transferred to 4.

Tank 4 is the settling tank, and not shown in the blueprint is the distribution pump that draws out of the top of tank 4, controlled by a level sensor.

So, on initial startup Tank 1 fills up first, and begins flowing out of the overflow into Tank 2.

Once Tank 3 reaches the level of the the inlet on Tank 4, Tank 4 fills to the same level as Tank 3, at which point they begin filling together, along with Tank 2, until they reach the level sensor and turn on the distribution pump.

So in my scenario, "Full" is whatever the designer planned it to be, and not all tanks are designed purely for holding liquid, they often are to contain liquid while a process is occurring, and so you have to look at the design of the system to determine what the proper tank level is.

Assumptions: 1) The tubes are large enough versus the flow into tank 1 such that (mostly), the tanks fill according to their relative connections and vertical elevations 2) Gravity is "pulling down"
It's fairly obvious that tanks 3 and 4 would "fill to overflowing" very nearly at the same time... HOWEVER :-)

Think about this. If tank 3 and 4 were perfectly constructed, they would both hold the same vertical level of water molecules at equilibrium.
BUT, since the water molecules are entering tank 3 first, causing tank 3's level to be at least 1 molecule "higher" in order to cause a pressure differential that causes a flow into tank 4, the level in tank 3 will always be either equal to the level in tank 4, or a molecule higher than tank 4 temporarily, in the process of filling to their "overflow" level.

This is slightly muddied by the fact that a flow has momentum, which might actually cause a slight oscillation in the the tank 3/tank 4 levels at various flow rates into the system....but generally, tank 3 will fill first.

Okay, so first, there just isn't nearly enough info given to come up with an educated answer. One of the more important pieces of info needed here isn't necessarily the rate of flow from the hose into container 1; but rather the rate of flow from the hose into container 1 RELATIVE to the rate of flow OUT of container 1. So not really any hard, precise data needed there, just need the relative rate of flow in/out. Also-assuming each tube coming out of the containers are all the same measurement-knowing the diameter of the tubes that allow the water to flow from one container to the next would be very important. I assume 3. Up to 3, it's simple. As soon as the water gets to the level of the connection, the next one starts filling. What adds the twist is the connection between 3 and 4, which isn't level.

What happens there is that the connection slowly fills along with 3 until it reaches the part that connects to 4. Then 4 fills up to match 3. After that, they both fill at about the same rate, and thus fill at almost the same time.

However, water takes time to move from one side to the other, and so 3 will be filled slightly before 4 is filled.

(After that, 2 has filled up to the level of the top of 3, and fills up, with 1 starting to fill once it gets to the level of the connector, with 2 filling and one then finally filling up.)

Hey Physics Girl, can you perhaps moderate how you talk about "23andMe"? In particular can you avoid making absolute statements about the genetic make-up of humans - not everyone has 23 pairs of chromosomes. I appreciate you're a Physics Girl, and not a Biology Girl, but I'm sure you can appreciate that there are very many people* without exactly 23 pairs of chromosomes and that the majority would consider themselves human.


*people with monosomy (e.g. Turner symdrome), or trisomy (e.g. Down syndrome, or Triple X syndrome), those with Klinefelter syndrome (which isn't always considered a trisomy), and those people with additional chunks of a chromosome (which isn't enough to count as a trisomy) who may very well go through life undiagnosed. See https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3330224/ for more details. Even a low rate of long-term survivor of these types of conditions adds up to a large number of people when there are several billion people on the planet.

Let's assume all tubes are the same cross sectional area. There is additional pressure drop from #3 to #4 so with low flow rate it will always be #3 (dP will always be > 0 if there is flow so it will fill JUST before #4). Above a certain higher flow rate it will be #1 as flow coming in is greater than natural flow through the pipe to #2. It would never be #2 or #4.

The riddle at 5:41. Assuming yada yada about gravity and flow rate / flow restrictions, and all containers are open / no "vacuum pressures."
A spills over to B. B spills over to C. C would spill over to D, but is blocked, so spills over to J. J "tries" to spill over into I, but ultimately spills into L before getting any fluid into I. L would spill to H, but is also blocked, so instead spills to F. F and L fill now, but the top of F is lower than the top of L, so F fills first.
If the blockage from C to D is removed, then G would fill first. The fact that the outlet from D is below the top of G doesn't matter, since all containers are open at the top.
If the blockage from L to H is removed, then H fills before F, so H fills first.
